content.description:
Begin by climbing the tree until able to transition onto the rock; a sling around the tree provides some protection before the first bolt. Once established on the face traverse slightly left and then launch up thin, technical moves to a somewhat pumping finish on larger holds.

Overall a very good route with a scenic location, excellent rock and intriguing movement that's a welcome diversion from the slab climbing so common to the area.
content.location: This atypical route is found on the bulging west face of the formation which has a large pine tree growing near the base.

climbs.name: Limp Dick
climbs.fa: FA Mark Powell, Harry Daley, and Dave Rearick, May 1959  FFA Tom Higgins, May 1969

content.description: An aesthetic and exciting mantle and undercling lead up to a fun, easy face.  There isn't much difficult climbing on this route, but it takes you to an interesting summit.
content.protection: just a few pieces - mainly small  There are bolts on top.

content.description:
Climb the tree that

Pinhead

starts from as high as you possibly can, and then transition onto the rock when possible. Belay/rap from bolts atop Pinhead.

An unusual climb that in theory may get easier as the tree grows taller! Take some slings to tie off branches for protection if so inclined.
content.protection: Sturdy pine tree, slings for tying off branches, bolted anchor/rap
content.location: Located on the southwest corner of the Limp Dick formation, just to the right of Pinhead.

climbs.name: Fallatio
climbs.fa: John Long, Eric Accomazzo, Richard Harrison, and Royd Riggins, 1973

content.description: A fun, strenuous crux move by a bolt is followed by 140 feet of easy, unprotected face climbing.  The spelling here is from the current guidebook.  Earlier guidebooks used the more expected "fellatio" spelling.  Do a short rappel north from the summit.
content.protection: one protection bolt and belay/rappel bolts on top

climbs.name: Dickhead
climbs.fa: Jonny Woodward and Darrell Hensel, July 1988

content.description:
Climb the face past the obvious features (dishes etc...) passing zero bolts.  The crux is at the top.  Woodward bouldered it until he felt comfortable commiting to the move.

It might be possible to stack multiple pads in a manner that would keep one from getting hurt and also prevent going down the hill after landing.
content.protection: None.  Solo or TR.  The stray bolt near the bottom (to the right) is not part of the route.

content.description: This climb is on the long northeast face of the rock.  For the approach, scramble high up the gully on the left side of Sunshine Wall.  It starts near the tunnel used to access the South Face.  The climb is a short, very enjoyable steep pocketed face with good protection.  Shortly above the second bolt, the difficulty eases up considerably, and you can scramble to the top.  The second bolt was placed more for protection of the second person than for the leader.  The first ascensionists claim that they considered "Hard On" for the route's name before settling on Dick Tracy.
content.protection: two bolts and perhaps one or two wired nuts
